channel.title: Pasting a Code isn't enough. I want to know what it means
channel.description:
Hello, My name is Shawn. Introduced to RSPS's by my good friend Corey about a month ago. For the past month I've basically looked for a source that i could basically leech, which I'm here to change because learning how to code java would be accomplishment in my live which could ultimately give me some confidence. Now Source wise I have no idea what to start with. I saw a comment by a user named I Vain I to use Hyperion, I think is the name. So I downloaded it, and had no idea where to start and saw that no tut's were really made on a basic of this so i then heard about delta's and PI's and 474's. I understand the difference's now. (sorta :P) Anyway now that i see most of the most experienced people coding Java use bases like Hyperion, I'm thinking i should start on a delta.
Now, obviously i could download a source with already made god sword's, claws, a stable (for delta) source..etc..But to me that's not good enough. And if i got a blank source i could easily ask people on here a for a Claw Gfx(i think thats what it's called) spec and emote. But i want to understand and learn how to build such codes on my own. Onto my questions.
-Q1 As a beginner, Should i use delta? -Q2 How do you begin to create codes which make your character to motions like the AGS special attack? (for example, How does a code make Java know to make your character jump in the air and do a full spin)? -Q3 People say you need to "add models" for claws or customs (spirit shields for example) I don't see a picture or anything in the sprites folders of deltas..So again how does a code suddenly create a item? -Q4 how do you make a source more stable? Is it just the computer you run on? I'm on a i5 preprocessor so if thats the case i shouldn't have a problem
Obviously..To many Java experts this is pocket change information, But if you'd be kind enough to share that information it would be greatly appreciated! Thank You! (sorry if any grammar was wrong, typed this extremely quick)

item.title: Pasting a Code isn't enough. I want to know what it means
item.dc:creator: @Viety Viety
item.description:
@Viety wrote:

Thank you. No need for such talk in a community where you attempt to learn.

Read full topic

[quote=“Viety, post:4, topic:369956”]Thank you, very helpful. People such as you and vengeance are what can a make a community like this great. I’m going to read and study java to the best of my ability and then come back and attempt to code a server, and make it not so much to get tons of players but personal gratification. Thank you.[/quote]Trust me, if you are gonna learn all of java you will kick RSPS in the ass and go make some of your own programs. But then yeah, good luck.

item.title: Pasting a Code isn't enough. I want to know what it means
item.dc:creator: @Viety Viety
item.description:
@Viety wrote:

_Vengeance:

If this is still too difficult, I advise staying away from here.

Ahhh maybe you are correct in the fact I’m a bit under educated in the way of server making creation. I’m going to take your heed and Learn what i can from the site you have provided. Honestly I’m going by what I heard once “if there’s a will there’s a way” Have you any other resources or advice that i might be able to make use of? I’ve very eager to learn and grow in the rsps community.

Read full topic
item.source: Pasting a Code isn't enough. I want to know what it means

item.title: Pasting a Code isn't enough. I want to know what it means
item.dc:creator: @_Vengeance _Vengeance
item.description:
@_Vengeance wrote:

  1. Hyperion is far superior. However, as a beginner, you should be looking to learn Java properly, prior to attempting to take on such a complex project.
  2. You don’t need to worry about any of that, as that’s all done client side. All your server needs to do, is send the correct packets to the client.
  3. This is client manipulation, and is unrelated to the programming of the server.
  4. This is done by constructing the server in an efficient manner, and accounting for any possible exploits/bugs.

Honestly, if you want to understand how these work, start smaller. Find some simple programs, from somewhere such as Planet Source Code, and analyse them. If this is still too difficult, I advise staying away from here, until you have read some (e-)books and have a better understanding of how Java, and programming in general, works.

Read full topic
item.source: Pasting a Code isn't enough. I want to know what it means
